awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Molecular Augmented Reality for Visualizing Complex Biomolecular Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to implement a Molecular Visualization System that will transform the complexities of understanding biomolecular structures via hands-on interaction using augmented reality (AR) technology. Users will "interact" with three-dimensional molecular compounds and pre-programmed animations using transformative hand gestures to facilitate scaling and rotations. Molecular manipulations of chemical compounds will be more intuitive and replace the traditional computer graphic interface. The natural interaction will ultimately allow users to gain closer insight into molecular structures and conformations. The three-dimensional viewpoint of chemical structures will enable a transformative learning environment for its users. The system allows a shared experience facilitating enhanced group discovery processes.  The system also modernizes the learning environment for higher education and enables discovery and collaboration processes in corporate environments.

This I-Corps project creates a tool for understanding molecular forms and allows for enhanced exploration and discovery. Current technology enables professionals in chemical and biological sciences to discover, analyze, and manipulate physical forms. Additionally, the more advanced technology supports the ability to capture and visualize molecular forms at a smaller scale, resulting in greater visual understanding. However, a drawback of some of these current systems is that they rely on complex chemistry software and often have poor interfaces that greatly limit the ability to visualize and manipulate biomolecules. The Molecular Visualization System developed here aims to ultimately alter the path of implementation from limited chemistry interfaces to direct, hands-on manipulation of chemical models using wearable AR. This shift can transform the discovery process into a more interactive and intuitive experience. The primary goal is for students and educators to utilize the mobile application bridging the gap between theoretical concepts and practical applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
The MADE (Molecular Augmented Reality for Design and Engineering) application is an augmented reality (AR) tool that allows users to visualize complex macromolecules in an interactive and exploratory environment. Developing and designing MADE required a thorough analysis of user segments, which informed the commercial prospects of MADE’s smartphone and HMD(Head Mounted Display) application. To determine the user’s needs and corresponding value propositions, a set of customer discovery interviews were conducted with individuals from MADE’s potential user segments. Through the customer discovery process, active user engagement revealed unique value propositions and helped identify user segments of higher education students, professors, and life science professionals. For the aforementioned user segments, the design of the MADE application serves as an educational tool for an enhanced learning experience, as well as a collaboration tool for exploratory drug development and discovery. The discovery and design process for MADE revealed the viability of the application for commercialization in the higher education and life science profession markets. Based on the results from the customer discovery process, such as interviews during the NSF I-Corp course and attended tradeshows/conferences, we gathered our customer segments and value propositions to adopt MADE. 

Under the NSF I-Corps grant, we have updated the BMC (Business Model Canvas). Our updated BMC reflects our customer segments of:

  1. University undergraduate junior chemistry, biochemistry, and biomolecular engineering students.
  2. University graduate chemistry, biochemistry, biomolecular engineering, structural bioinformatics, and structural biology students.
  3. University educational and instructional technology support.
  4. Business/marketing people to introduce their biochemistry product.

Discovery of the value propositions for higher education value adoption in University.  Our proposed value propositions include:

  1. Readily accessible software that reduces the learning curve compared to existing computer-based programs.
  2. Increased understanding of complex molecular structures measured by an increase in quiz and exam scores.
  3. Increased engagement and student understanding of structures to guide discussions and presentations.
  4. Increased student understanding of complex molecular structures is measured by higher quiz and exam averages.
  5. A higher GPA reflects a boost in student academic performance.

Complex macromolecular structures are best understood using 3D visualizations, as they provide the opportunities to gather multiple perspectives of molecular details. The education sector can benefit from utilizing 3D visualizations through MADE, as it can enhance the academic setting. Professors can cultivate a more interactive and engaging classroom environment, providing students the opportunity to gain a better understanding of 3D structures. Professors can supplement existing course material and use MADE as an additional tool within the classroom. Students are provided a new avenue to explore and understand the material, as 3D visualizations offer detailed representations to information retention. For the marketing purpose, they need to explain their own product using the MADE to show their model of molecular after they create 3D visualizations.

We recognize the need to develop from the existing computational software for complex 3D structure visualizations, which requires a substantial understanding of terminology. Also, the existing software often has a learning curve, requiring time to utilize its full potential effectively. 

 We identified market needs for MADE during the introduction and presentation at the Tradeshow and conference. This customer discovery process identified a market need for MADE. However, additional research, design, and further investigation of the customer discovery process may be required. MADE shows promising opportunity.  For the business market situation, MADE can introduce its company model using a 3D AR system at the biochemistry conference and Tradeshow. We found a specific opportunity in this customer segment. Due to increased customer needs, this segment will make our product fast-growing and develop with reasonable financial support.

Identified device and platform needs.The lack of smartphone use during instruction creates new challenges in implementing MADE in an academic setting. Generally, professors discourage students from using smartphones during lectures to avoid distractions and losing concentration from lecture content. However, there may be opportunities for professors to allot lab time or dedicated class time for exploratory tools that may serve as a discussion mechanism. As gathered from our interviews, professors need visualizations to create engaging discussions and presentations. They find that engaging course materials cultivate an effective environment for student success. Although smartphones are not heavily utilized today as a classroom tool, smartphone-assisted academic instruction may be the norm in the future, where laptops, tablets, and smartphones would be used interchangeably.

The next steps for MADE involve a study design to validate or invalidate the effectiveness of smartphone implementation in an academic setting. This study will help determine if MADE results in better grades and understanding amongst students studying complex macromolecular structures and will verify the efficacy of 3D molecular visualizations. This study will be a crucial step in the validation of MADE's potential in the academic sector.

For future software development steps, engage with AI software for rich education content and business fundamentals for new segments.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2024
Modified by: Hyejin H Kum-Biocca
